description: '''Henry Mobley''' (July 7, 1930 – May 30, 1986) was an American tenor saxophonist and composer. Mobley was described by [[Leonard Feather]] as the "middleweight champion of the tenor saxophone", a metaphor used to describe his tone, that was neither as aggressive as [[John Coltrane]] nor as mellow as [[Lester Young]], and his style that was laid-back, subtle and melodic, especially in contrast with players such as Coltrane and [[Sonny Rollins]]. The critic Stacia Proefrock claimed him "one of the most underrated musicians of the bop era." Mobley's compositions include "Double Exposure", "Soul Station", and "Dig Dis".
